description: From Middle English galingale, from Old French galingal, from Arabic خَلَنْجَان‎ (ḵalanjān), from Persian قولنجان‎ (qulenjân, qulanjân), from Sanskrit कुलञ्जन (kulañjana), perhaps from Chinese 高良薑／高良姜 (gāoliángjiāng), from 高涼／高凉 (Gāoliáng) (a prefecture or county in China) + 薑／姜 (jiāng, “ginger”).

examples: An early English version [of marmelade] was called charedequynce, of which one version included wine, honey, ginger, galingale, cinnamon and wardens as well as quinces.

entries.meaning: One of several species of Cyperus sedges with aromatic rhizomes.
